items.title: Grammys 2026: Follow live updates on the biggest night in music
Red carpet highlights from the 2026 Grammy Awards
items.summary_auto: All the must-see looks from music’s biggest night.

items.title: Montrealers call for end to U.S. immigration crackdown at anti-ICE protest
items.summary_auto: Demonstrators gathered in Montreal on Sunday to protest the immigration crackdown by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, calling out the law enforcement agency's tactics as well as Canadian "complicity" in them.

items.title: Kerri Einarson to play for 5th Canadian women's curling title and Kaitlyn Lawes her 2nd
items.summary_auto: Canada's Kerri Einarson is returning to the championship game at the Scotties Tournament of Hearts following a 12-5 rout of Alberta's Selena Sturmay on Sunday in Mississauga, Ont.

items.title: Hamilton soldier who died in Latvia was 'immensely proud' to be part of Canadian military, says father
items.summary_auto: Sebastian Halmagean, originally from Hamilton, was a gunner based at the 5th Canadian Division Support Base Gagetown in Oromocto, N.B., on his first deployment to Latvia.

items.title: Rafah border crossing into Gaza opened for limited passage, Israel says
items.summary_auto: Israel reopened the Rafah border crossing on Sunday for people to travel between Gaza and Egypt, the first opening of effectively the sole route in or out of the Palestinian territory since May 2024. Israel seized the border crossing in May 2024, nine months after it launched attacks on the region.

items.title: Quebec family forced to return to Mexico after mother says she failed French exam by 1 point
items.summary_auto: Between new language requirements put in place in 2024 and the abolition of another pathway to permanent residency, some international students in Quebec feel betrayed.

items.title: Medical personnel to be evacuated from Kashechewan First Nation, still under state of emergency
items.summary_auto: Indigenous Services Canada says it anticipates to evacuate all nurses and paramedics still working in Kashechewan First Nation on Monday. Approximately 300 people remain in the community, including children.

items.title: 5-year-old Liam Ramos and father return to Minnesota from Texas detention facility
items.summary_auto: A five-year-old boy and his father detained by immigration officers in Minnesota and held in Texas have been released following a judge's order. They have returned to Minnesota, according to the office of U.S. Democratic Rep. Joaquin Castro.

items.title: Pakistan forces kill 145 separatist militants in 40-hour battle
items.summary_auto: Pakistani security forces killed 145 militants in a 40-hour battle launched as a series of co-ordinated gun and bomb attacks across Balochistan left nearly 50 people dead, the province's chief minister said on Sunday.

items.title: More than a dozen people killed in Ukraine after Russian drone strikes miners' bus
items.summary_auto: Fifteen people were killed and seven wounded after a Russian drone struck a bus carrying miners in Ukraine's southeastern Dnipropetrovsk region, energy firm DTEK ​and government officials said on Sunday.

items.title: Meet the doctors for Canada’s men’s and women’s Olympic hockey teams — who happen to be married
items.summary_auto: Laura Bennion and Ian Auld are the lead physicians for Canada's women's and men's hockey teams.

items.title: Power outages hit Ukraine and Moldova as Kyiv faces winter cold
items.summary_auto: Emergency power cuts swept across several Ukrainian cities as well as neighbouring Moldova on Saturday, officials said, amid a commitment from the Kremlin to U.S. President Donald Trump to pause strikes on Kyiv as Ukraine battles one of its bleakest winters in years.

items.title: Iran's Khamenei warns any U.S. attack would spark 'regional war'
items.summary_auto: Iran's supreme leader warned Sunday that any attack by the United States would spark a "regional war" in the Middle East, further escalating tensions as U.S. President Donald Trump has threatened to militarily strike the Islamic Republic over its crackdown on recent nationwide protests.

items.title: Alcaraz, 22, beats Djokovic to win Australian Open, becoming youngest man to complete career Grand Slam
items.summary_auto: Carlos Alcaraz is the youngest man ever to complete a career Grand Slam after securing the Australian Open title against Novak Djokovic, who had never lost in his 10 previous finals at Melbourne Park.

items.title: Blairmore latest Alberta community to lose bank branch — a trend seen across Canada
items.summary_auto: The loss of retail banking service locations is not unique to one bank or to Alberta or to small towns. The Canadian Bankers Association says the number of bank branches is down nationwide: about six per cent from 2020 to 2024. But the closures hit harder in small communities where the options are fewer and farther apart.

items.title: FDA warns ‘Dr. Goodenowe’ health centre founder that his recent supplement study put patient health at risk
items.summary_auto: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has rebuked the founder of Moose Jaw’s controversial Dr. Goodenowe Restorative Health Center, alleging that a recent clinical trial of his supplements put the safety and welfare of research subjects at risk.

items.title: New fund addressing intimate partner violence honours Cape Breton woman killed last year
items.summary_auto: The Elizabeth Fry Society's new fund to provide greater education on intimate partner violence is dedicated to a Cape Breton woman who was killed last November.

items.title: Despite the lack of groundhogs, N.L. has its own Feb. 2 traditions
items.summary_auto: Monday morning at sunrise, Punxsutawney Phil will emerge from his burrow and, if he sees his shadow, North America is supposedly in for six more weeks of winter.

items.title: Toronto-based Mexican musician cancels U.S. tour after ICE shootings, as artists reconsider American shows
items.summary_auto: Industry reps say Canadian musicians are increasingly concerned about touring the U.S., traditionally their biggest market, amid rising political tensions and Trump's immigration crackdown.

items.title: Kashechewan teen evacuated to Niagara Falls, Ont., says she misses 'being on the land'
items.summary_auto: Kashechewan residents Kerri-Ann Koosees and Keisha Paulmartin were forced to evacuate to Niagara Falls on short notice after the First Nation declared a state of emergency. Despite concerns and challenges, they say they're grateful for city and local groups trying to meet their needs.

items.title: Fact-checking Trump's claims about his 1st year back in the White House
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump likes to throw out a lot of figures during speeches to his base that he says prove how successful his first year back in office has been. But given Trump's proclivity for spreading misinformation, we wanted to see how many of these figures are accurate and backed up by real data.

items.title: Former campaign manager says Conservatives should link U.S. relations to cost of living
items.summary_auto: Former Conservative campaign manager Jenni Byrne says her party's messaging on the relationship between Canada and the United States is evolving, and should continue evolving as the situation shifts.

items.title: How a Canadian in Rome is building a Catholic AI from Vatican archives
items.summary_auto: A Canadian entrepreneur in Rome is building Magisterium AI, a Catholic platform trained on church documents and Vatican-linked collections. The project aims to make doctrine searchable at scale, while raising questions about accuracy, authority and how it will be used.
